answers.answer: Hi,The cause of this decreasing GFR needs to be assessed first. Differentials will be infections like pyelonephritis, inflammatory conditions like glomerulonephritis, an undiagnosed diabetes mellitus,polycystic kidneys , renovascular disease and certain drugs.A kidney ultrasound, a complete blood count to rule out anemia, a 24 hour urine collection for urine albumin levels , and serum levels of electrolytes ( potassium, calcium ) may be able to shed some light on this.I feel that this worries you . Just be proactive about this and continue to reassure your husband.Your husband's GFR may need to be closely monitored. Also,openly communicate with your physicians. Let us take this one step at a time.

question: My husband is 44 years old and is in good health.  He works out (lifts weights,runs) several times each week.  He does not smoke or drink.  He takes Zetia (10 mg) once daily and 500 mg of Naproxen twice daily as needed.  He recently went in for his yearly physical and his creatinine level was found to be high, as was his GFR.  Here is his results over the past year:Creatinine                               GFR1/10/07                   1.3 mg/dl                              641/10/08                   1.4                                       591/22/08                   1.5                                       542/20/08                   1.6                                       50His doctor is referring him on to a nephrologist about this.  He has had no symptoms that something isn't right.  Could this be a sign of kidney disease?  We're very worried?  Thanks.
title: Husband's Decreasing Kidney Function
